revealed_symptoms.ulceration: It’s like a cut or sore that just won’t heal, and sometimes it scabs over but comes right back.
revealed_symptoms.border irregularity: The edges are all jagged, kinda messy, not smooth like my other moles.
revealed_symptoms.satellite lesions: There are these little dots or spots popping up near the main one, like it’s spreading.
revealed_symptoms.induration: It feels thicker or harder than the rest of my skin, like there's something under there.
revealed_symptoms.asymmetry: One side of this mole looks different from the other, like it's lopsided or uneven.
revealed_symptoms.spontaneous bleeding: Sometimes this spot just starts bleeding out of nowhere, even if I don’t touch it.

hidden_symptoms.diameter >6mm: It’s bigger than the eraser on a pencil, and I feel like it’s still growing.
hidden_symptoms.color variation: It’s got a bunch of different colors—like brown, black, maybe even some red or blue mixed in.
hidden_symptoms.evolving: This thing keeps changing—getting darker, bigger, or just looking different than before.
hidden_symptoms.erythema: The skin around it looks red or puffy, like it’s irritated or reacting to something.
hidden_symptoms.shiny or waxy bump: It looks kinda like a smooth, shiny pimple, but it never pops or goes away.
hidden_symptoms.telangiectasia: There are these tiny, spidery red blood vessels around the spot that I didn’t notice before.

patient_history.content: Hi, I'll be your doctor today. What brings you in?

Well, I have this spot, it's like a cut or sore that just won’t heal, and sometimes it scabs over but comes right back. The edges are all jagged, kinda messy, not smooth like my other moles. There are these little dots or spots popping up near the main one, like it’s spreading. It also feels thicker or harder than the rest of my skin, like there's something under there. One side of this mole looks different from the other, like it's lopsided or uneven. And sometimes this spot just starts bleeding out of nowhere, even if I don’t touch it.

Thank you for sharing this information. To get a clearer picture, could you tell me if this spot ever itches or feels painful? Also, have you noticed any changes in sensation, like numbness or tingling, around the area?
No, it doesn’t really itch or hurt, and I haven't noticed any numbness or tingling.
Thanks for clarifying that. Can you tell me a bit about how long you've had this spot? Also, have you had a lot of sun exposure over your lifetime, or has anyone in your family had skin cancer?

I've had this spot for a while now, I'm not sure exactly how long. As for sun exposure, yeah, I've been out in the sun quite a bit over the years. And no, no one in my family has had skin cancer that I know of.
Thank you. To better understand the spot, could you tell me, has the size of this spot changed recently? Has it changed in shape or color, or is it pretty much the same as when you first noticed it?
Well, now that you mention it, this thing keeps changing—getting darker, bigger, or just looking different than before.

Thank you for that information. Based on your description and the changes you've noticed, it's important to rule out skin cancer. I recommend further evaluation. I will need to perform a physical examination of the spot and potentially order a biopsy.
Okay, that sounds good. What happens next?

I'll need to perform a physical examination of the spot to check it carefully. I might also need to take a small sample of the spot, called a biopsy, to examine it under a microscope. This will help determine the exact cause of the changes. I understand that you're worried, but rest assured, we will take appropriate steps to diagnose and treat it.

I will schedule you for a physical examination. During the exam, I will thoroughly check the spot and assess whether a biopsy is necessary. We'll discuss the results and the next steps together once all of the information has been collected.

I understand that this can be a bit concerning, but the physical examination and a potential biopsy will help us figure out exactly what's going on. These procedures are important for us to diagnose and treat the spot appropriately. We will schedule a time for you to come in soon.
Alright, I will be waiting for your call to schedule the appointment.

It also feels thicker or harder than the rest of my skin, like there's something under there. One side of this mole looks different from the other, like it's lopsided or uneven. And sometimes this spot just starts bleeding out of nowhere, even if I don’t touch it.
